page.title: 07IRRIGATION
page.content: It is becoming increasingly common in this area to supplement the natural rainfall (of approximately 28 inches per annum) by artificial watering systems. This has a beneficial effect on the yields of root crops and vegetables, and also helps to combat certain plant diseases which are prevalent during particularly dry seasons. Potato scab is a disease which can be greatly reduced by adequate watering at certain times. Unfortunately, the main source of irrigation water in this area is the Kenley Burn, and as a result of water being pumped on to the fields, the level of the burn can become dangerously low, and the concentration of agricultural chemicals from field run-off has consequently increased to unacceptable levels.
